awd_titl_txt: AF: Medium: Algorithms for Scalable Phylogenetic Network Inference
awd_abstract_narration:
Species phylogenies model how species split and diverge and provide important insight into fundamental biological phenomena and processes, including biodiversity, and trait evolution, while gene trees provide insight into protein structure and function as well as systems biology. Advances in sequencing technologies and assembly methods and the availability of whole-genome datasets have opened up the possibility of transformative improvements in accuracy for estimating species phylogenies and gene trees. Phylogenetic networks extend phylogenetic trees to provide an appropriate model of reticulate evolutionary histories. Reticulate evolution describes the origination of a lineage through partial merging of two ancestor lineages. Recently developed methods allow for statistical inference of phylogenetic networks in order to account for other processes that could be at play during the evolution of the genomes. However, these methods can handle fewer than a handful of genomes. This award will develop methods for estimating large-scale phylogenetic networks from sequence data as well as gene tree estimates. The award will stimulate research in computer science and statistics and will have a major impact on evolutionary biology. The award will contribute open-source code to the PhyloNet software package. Lectures and tutorials will be given to the community on the developments made in the award and on the use of PhyloNet. The award will provide ample opportunities for training students and post-doctoral fellows in cutting-edge, interdisciplinary algorithmic research.

The project will be carried out through five activities that are intertwined throughout the lifetime of the award. (1) Development of novel algorithmic techniques for scalable inference of phylogenetic networks that allow for analyzing data sets with tens and even hundreds of genomes. (2) Implementation and of all methods in the PhyloNet software package. (3) Thorough evaluation of the methods in terms of accuracy and computational requirements. (4) Mentoring and training of students and post-doctoral fellows. (5) Dissemination of the results through an open-source software package, publications in peer-reviewed journals and conference proceedings, lectures and tutorials, and course materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Phylogenetic networks extend the phylogenetic tree model to allow for capturing non-treelike evolutionary histories that arise in the presence of evolutionary processes such as hybridization, horizontal gene transfer, and gene flow. The shape, or topology, of a phylogenetic network is that of a rooted, directed, acyclic graph. The nodes and edges of the network have associated continuous values that capture evolutionary parameters such as the population mutation rate. 

Methods for inference of phylogenetic networks have been developed for several decades. In the particular, the last decade has seen several maximum likelihood and Bayesian inference methods of phylogenetic networks from multi-locus genomic data. A major bottleneck facing the applicability of those methods is their scalability, as likelihood calculations are compute-intensive, which has limited their applicability to small data sets in terms of the numbers of genomes and genomic loci in the data set. 

This project focused on the scalability of these methods and made several impactful contributions. The project investigated the feasibility of tree-based inference of networks. In such an approach, a tree is first inferred and it is then augmented to a network to fit the data better. This is a fast approach since much progress has been made on efficient tree inference. However, the findings indicate the approach could result in inaccurate inferences. The project also resulted in the development of the first divide-and-conquer approach for phylogenetic networks while accounting for incomplete lineage sorting. This approach scales up to hundreds of genomes and loci and provides accurate inferences. A major challenge here is the accurate inference of sub-networks while accounting for different sources of rate heterogeneity. The project investigated the impact of model misspecification on network inference and developed new techniques for accounting for rate heterogeneity across loci and across branches in the Bayesian inference methods. 

All methods were disseminated through publications in top journals and conference proceedings as well as talks and presentations. Furthermore, all methods have been implemented in PhyloNet, which is a publicly available software package for phylogenetic network inference and is the most comprehensive package in terms of methods for inference of explicit phylogenetic networks. Materials from the project are also incorporated into a graduate course that the PI teaches. 

The project provided ample opportunities for training graduate and undergraduate students as well as a software developer and postdoctoral fellows.
